thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: Former Army soldier accused of supporting fake ISIS attack
thread.title_full: Former Army soldier accused of supporting fake ISIS attack

author: CHRISTOPHER BRENNAN
title: Former Army soldier accused of supporting fake ISIS attack
text:
Former Army soldier accused of supporting fake ISIS attack in Kansas City Former Army soldier accused of supporting fake ISIS attack Robert Lorenzo Hester Jr. is accused of attempting to support the Islamic State. (Boone County Sheriffs Departmen) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   9:09 PM 
An Army vet has been accused of helping in a fake Presidents’ Day terrorist attack against buses and train stations in Kansas City. 
Robert Lorenzo Hester was charged with attempting to supply material support to a sting Islamic State attack he wanted to be “10 times more” than the Boston Marathon bombing , federal prosecutors announced Tuesday. 
The 26-year-old, who converted to Islam and also went by names including Mohammed Junaid Al Amrecki, was contacted by undercover FBI agents after posting radical views on social media, according to a complaint filed Sunday. 
Among his alleged posts last year was one saying that ISIS was “created by U.S. And Israeli government,” though he was accused of later turning towards the terrorist group. 
Mattis pivots from Trump's remarks to seize Iraqi oil 
Hester, who served less than a year in the Army before being discharged in 2013, eventually went from social media messages with the fake ISIS supporters to encrypted chat messages and in-person meetings with one. 
The Missouri native’s meetings at the end of last year with the fake “brother” who tried to test his commitment to the cause, gave him money and also threatened his family if he shared any information. 
After months of the agents talking with him, the suspect allegedly acquired bomb-making materials such as duct tape, wire and roofing nails at the beginning of this month. 
Hester told one agent who showed him a supply of rifles that he approved of the idea that the items would make explosives that would kill people, according to the FBI allegations. 
U.S.-backed Iraqi forces advance on ISIS-held western Mosul 
He was arrested after being driven to a storage facility by a fake terrorist. 
The former soldier has two small children and is expecting a third, according to the Kansas City Star. 
His wife would not comment when reached by the newspaper Tuesday. Join the Conversation:
